text:
PAX: It's my pleasure to
introduce Professor Ellen

Kuhl, who is the
Walter B. Reinhold

professor in the
School of Engineering,

as well as the Robert Bosch
chair of mechanical engineering
here at Stanford.

So she's passionate
about understanding

about improving
human health through
computational simulation.

Her expertise is in
living matter physics,

which is the use of theoretical
and computational models

to simulate and predict the
behavior of living matter.

So we're going to learn a lot
more about that in a second.

And one thing that was
interesting in your bio

kind of a subset
of that is you're

also a founding member of the
Living Heart Project, which

is a translational
project that's

aiming to revolutionize
cardiovascular science

through the use of realistic
simulations of the human heart,
presumably.

And so in addition to
that, I should also

add that she is also
quite an athlete.

So you are a three-time
qualifier for the Kona Ironman

World championship, as well
as a three-time All-American

triathlete and a
marathon runner,

including the Boston
and New York Marathon.

So what you do as an athlete
in your spare time, most of us
would do as our full-time job.

But we're super excited
to have you here today

to learn a little bit more about
this idea of automated model

discovery and how that's
revolutionizing science
right now.

So I think a great
place to start

would be if you could just
give us a little bit more

about your background, and in
particular, the living matter

lab and what you're
researching and doing there.
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah, sure.

Yeah, thanks, Pax,
for having me.
Yeah.

So in the living
matter lab, what we do

is we design physics-based
tools that we

embed in machine
learning, and then

we model living systems
as you just said.
And you mentioned the heart.

So we're doing
this for the heart.

We do this also for arteries,
for the lung, for muscle,

and then most recently, what
people find most interesting
is the brain.

And we work a lot
here at Stanford

with people in the clinic,
people who design or use

devices, for instance, heart
valves that go into the heart,

to help them design
a therapy that's
targeted for a certain person.

And then because
I'm an engineer,

it's always centers
around forces

and stresses to
really understand

the forces in the heart
that these devices change.

PAX: And so can you give us
a little bit more about--

I mean, obviously
a part of that is
modeling how the heart works.

We're going to get into
the automated model
discovery in a second.

But how were-- what's one
special about soft matter

versus say modeling something
like a steel or a metal,

and how was that
done in the past?

ELLEN KUHL: Yeah,
that's a great point.

So the way people have
done this in the past--

I mean, people have modeled
materials like for a century
probably.

And they've always
gone and tested it.

And then they fit some
data points to a curve.
And that was their model.

And so a lot of people
have attached their name
to a certain model.

So you probably know
the Hooke's spring.
There's for rubber.

There's the Ogden rubber model
or the Mooney-Rivlin model.

And so people have
just attached a name.

And now years later, you can
just go to a library of models

and say, I want to use
the Holzapfel supple

model, which is developed
by Gerhard Holzapfel.

And so now you just go through
this library of hundreds

different models, and then you
fit your material to that one
model that you like.

And that's important
because then you can test,

you can use the
model, and hopefully

also predict what it would
do in other settings.
PAX: And how are those--

so how do you go about
selecting that model?

Is that require that
you have an expertise?
I mean, what level of expertise?
How does that happen?
Do you need to be--
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

So I think you're hitting
the critical part here,

and that's really
finding a good model.

And so in the past,
people were just

selecting one of this
big library of models.

And they would just
go in and find the one
that they think is good.

And to do that right,
you would probably

have to read a lot of
books on material modeling

or take classes in continuum
mechanics, finite elements

as a student, or read up on
it in manuals of textbooks.

It was really a limited
to experts in the field.

And I think what we
found really tricky

when I teach students
is to teach them

to use the right model
and select the best model,

because it really
requires experience

and it limits the
use of these tools

to really people who are
super well trained in it.

And so what we thought is,
can we automate that process

and make it more available to
broader usership of people?

When I work with
someone in the hospital,

they are not experts in
mechanics or physics.

They haven't taken
these classes,

and still they want
to model something.

So can we make it safe for
them to use these tools?

PAX: And so that leads us maybe
to automated model discovery,
which is kind of the focus here.

So can you talk a little bit
about what this process is

and how it's different from that
old process of someone created

a model and then you go into
a library of potential models,

and you select one, and then
apply it to your situation?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

And that's the
great question is,
can we automate that process?

Can we make take the user out
of this equation of selecting

and actually make it
less prone to error?

And so what we have
done-- and actually, it's

a very new method that
people have started

to develop over the last
two, three, four years,

is to use neural networks
to help select the model.

And so then you kind
of feed the information

that you have into
the network and use

networks that are
traditionally developed
for just other things.

I mean, the very powerful
tools for image recognition,

for example, but now tweak that
and use it for model discovery.
PAX: OK.
And then so-- can we back up?
So you said model discovery.
So it's model discovery.

And is it the same
time sort of selecting?

So can you walk through one
more time how that would work?

So say I'm a hospital-- say
I'm a doctor or something who
does not have a background.

How would I apply this,
or how would I use this?

I would have a set of data,
or I would have a situation
I want to apply it to.

Can you walk me through
that a little bit?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.
So ideally, you would have data.

With data, meaning, for example,
if we model say the heart,
there would be tests.

And ideally, there
are different tests.

So you can do like tension,
compression, shear, twist test

on little samples
of heart tissue.

And then you just
feed that information
into the neural network.

If you don't have
that now, I'm assuming
you don't have that at hand.

We have a website where we have
collected databases for heart,

for cardiovascular
tissue, brain tissue,

rubber just so that you can
get started and play with it.

And then that gets
fed into the network.

That's pretty much the
input to the network.
The network just runs.
And then it gives you a model.

And it gives you
model parameters.

PAX: So you talked earlier
about designing something
for a particular heart.

I mean, does this
work in terms of--

is there a difference
between modeling

hearts in general,
and using this
to model a particular heart?

Is there an ability to
personalize the model

that you're using to fit
the person that you're
developing something for?

ELLEN KUHL: So it depends on
what kind of tissue you want.

In this case, you probably
don't want to give me
a piece of your heart today.
But in general, yes.

So some pieces of
tissue, you can

just harvest from a person
and test and people do that,

or you would have an
aged group selection

down the road, where you say,
OK, this is a 50-year-old male.

It has this kind of
healthy heart conditions.
And we have a library for that.

And we're just starting
to build these things,
but that's a great question.

The question is, how
much does it differ?

And I would say probably
in a healthy person,

it differs by some
magnitude, but not too much.

So you could probably live
with someone else's data
that others have collected.

PAX: So if you already have
the data library, what would
be creating the different?

What are you adjusting to
create a different model?

ELLEN KUHL: So right now, we're
at the process of developing
this method for general things.

So when we have a data
library on the heart,

we could run it
through and develop
it to discover the best model.

Why is this different from
what people have done?

So what people have done
is they have just used
the model they have fitted.

But there's probably
hundreds of models,

and you don't know
what's the best.

Also, what we do is we
combine different models.

So the network-- you can think
of a neural network having

a number of different
nodes, say about 20.

So the model can discover
2 to the power of 20.

So that's 100,000 or more,
a million different models,

because it can combine
different and mix and match
different terms.

And so we have done
this and tried this.

And actually sometimes
we discover models

that already others have
used, which is nice.

Because out of
this 50,000 models,

you discover the holds up
the model, which is great.
But sometimes you don't.

And then you ask
yourself, OK, would people

have found this
with any other way?

Probably not, right, because
you wouldn't screen 50,000
different models by hand.

And so this is actually
great because you

have this vast overview
and library of things
you can choose from.
PAX: That's interesting.

And so neural networks
have been around, well,
for a fairly long time.

But there's something
unique about the way
you're doing this.

And I'm going to read it
here because it's called
constitutive neural networks.

So what are constitutive
neural networks,

and how are they--
what was the challenge

with the traditional
neural network,

and how did the
constitutive neural networks
address those challenges?

ELLEN KUHL: That's a great point
because you could technically

go ahead and just use a
neural network to do this.

You would take a neural
network off the shelf,
feed in your data.

Neural networks are great
at fitting functions.

Actually with any
number of these nodes,

they could approximate
any function
to any degree of accuracy.

That's just a
proof to show this.

But we want to fit
a specific function.

And we don't want to
use it for something

like image recognition, where
it is very good off the shelf,

but we want to build
physics into the network.
And we know the physics.

So for example, we
know when we pull
on something that usually--

and this is say an artery, it
gets harder over time to pull.

So it's kind of having
this exponential stiffening
behavior.

And we want to build
that information in.

And we also want
to build in that.

In physics, if
you measure forces

over deformation or
stress over strain,

you kind of have a
curve and not a zigzag.

And all that is in a way
built in the network.

So we hard wire physics into
the design, into the input,

into the output,
into the architecture

of the network itself, and
into the activation functions.

And after we've done
this, you, as the user,
don't need to worry about it.

So this network that
we have automatically
now satisfies all the physics.

And this is a trend
that has been around

for the last 5 or
maybe 10 years.

For constitutive models,
probably only three.

And it's constraining this
huge space of functions

that a neural network
could search over.

PAX: So it's putting rails
around or guidelines around it.

So you're not getting
something that
violates the laws of physics.

ELLEN KUHL: And then
you come with something

that actually you know
already a priori that it
satisfies everything.
PAX: And are those what you're--

and this is-- sorry,
I'm not technical.

So my question would be, the
guidelines or constraints that

you're putting in around
it at the physics,

are those models themselves,
or are they-- is there--
does that make sense?
Are you kind of putting--

having the model
develop in relationship

to existing to how we
model certain things
like stretching of arteries?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

So for example, we
can say, there's

a certain symmetry
to the material.

So it's the same from every
direction that you look at it,

we can build that in, or
you can build into it,

that when you're loading--
that unloading loaded,
it behaves the same way.
So it's elastic.

And certain things you
can just hardwire in.

And then also, we
want to make sure

that all these existing models
that people have developed
are a sub part of this.

So this is a natural
generalization

of what people have done,
but much, much broader.

You can think of a couple of
thousand models in this one
network.

PAX: And we had a question--
so I do want to get to this.

We had a question earlier come
in about using these models.

I mean, is this
something that's only

being run at Stanford
with high performance

computing or supercomputers,
or is this something

that someone can do at
home or at a hospital
or with more modest resources?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

I mean, we run this on
laptop just like this.

We have all the software on a
GitHub repository from our lab.

So you can find this
on our lab website.
You can just link it.

And also, what's
super cool and what

I'm most excited about is
if you want to use this--

a lot of people use this for
what's called finite element
simulation.

So they want to model
real structures,
like the real heart.

And so we've teamed up with
Dassault Systemes, which

is a company that actually
has one of the largest

finite element
packages called Abaqus.

And what they do is they use
our output of the network

to really use it, immediately
feed that into that simulation.

So that's like a
direct handshake

between what the model produces
and what the finite element
simulation can take in as input.
And this is very general.

So what is one example, you
can just already download it
from our website.

But you can also translate
that into any other package.

So the idea is it's
not just a standalone,

but it feeds immediately into
a simulation that anybody wants
to do with a larger structure.

PAX: And we have a good question
about the applications of this.

But before we maybe
jump into that,

one other thing that
I read about these

is that there is-- so
one of the concerns

about a lot of algorithms or
neural networks is they're
black boxes.
It's very hard.
You get an output.

You don't know how
it's getting there.

My understanding
is the constituents

of neural networks as opposed
to that are a little bit more
interpretable.

You're able to
understand the model.

You mentioned that already,
but could you maybe
elaborate on that?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

Thanks for bringing this
up, because that's true.

So a lot of times when you
just run a neural network,

you get some bit of a curve,
but nothing more than that.

And so here, you really
get some information
about say, the stiffness.

So it gives you
parameters that have

a unit of a
stiffness, or a shear

modulus, or Poisson ratio, or
just common physics parameters,
and also interpretable terms.

So you have a term
that's linear,

where you see in the
curve, it's linear

and then overlaid a
quadratic function.

And one can be related
say, to the matrix material
of the tissue.

And one can be related
to collagen fibers.

So you can really interpret the
terms and the parameters that

are otherwise just network
black box parameters really
have a physical meaning.

So they're real
physics parameters.
PAX: And so does that give--

I mean, especially if you're
using this for developing

a medical devices, that give you
more confidence in the accuracy

of the models, or does
it-- what does it--

can you build on
what it means for it
to be more interpretable?

ELLEN KUHL: Yeah, it's
a lot more helpful.

Because there's this
vast body of literature

where people have done
studies in the past,
so you can compare.

For instance, we now put
some data into the network.

You can say, Oh, this compares
well to a healthy artery,

or this looks more like a
diseased artery or something.

So you kind of have a
great base of comparison.

And exactly, I think
this is a criticism

from a lot of people in physics
or in our case, engineering,

that neural networks don't use
any of our prior knowledge.

And for decades,
engineers, or physicists,

mathematicians have really
built tools and an understanding
and insight into things.

And you don't want
to just lose that.
PAX: Right.

And just a quick--
because we see we
got a great question about.

So the models, are
they open source?

There's a link in the interface
to the Living Matter Lab.

And I believe there there's a
link to the GitHub repository.
So you can find a lot of--

ELLEN KUHL: So if anybody can't
find that, just reach out,
and we're happy to point you.

But it's all on our GitHub,
and it's called GitHub Living
Matter Lab.
And so you'll find it there.

PAX: So if you're interested
in learning more about it
or playing with it.

Well, and to that point, what
are some of the applications,

or what are the
things that you're

most excited about in
terms of this process,
the automated model?

ELLEN KUHL: I can give you
an example of something

that people have previously not
studied, where this is cool.

So over the summer with a bunch
of undergraduates in our lab,

we have tested a lot
of artificial meat.

And so that's a
cool application,

because a lot of people claim
that the perception of taste

is related to the
stiffness of the meat.

And so you think about you
eat like super soft tofu

and you feel it
doesn't taste right.

And it's not a good
meat replacement, right?
PAX: Interesting.

ELLEN KUHL: And so the
idea is of this product

is to match the mechanical
signature of real meat.

And that's not just
the stiffness, but also
the fibrous aspect.
So it's usually anisotropic.

It has a certain
fibrous structure
that the tissue has from--
there's muscle tissue mainly.

And so they tried to
recreate meat that
has the mechanics of real meat.

And nobody has a mechanical
model for artificial meat.

So we're like, Oh, we can
discover this with our network.

And actually it
works quite well.

So we just have tested a bunch
of the entire supermarket
shelf.

And actually it was
really cool study

because the students learned
how to use the device,
to use this new method.

And we discovered some
models actually out of it.
So that was cool.

PAX: So that's the
future of dining.

We'll have a texture, an actual
mechanical texture rating.

ELLEN KUHL: Well,
the real future

would be like, if
we can learn so

much, that we can design like
the best matching material.

PAX: So what this is doing
is you were testing the meat.

And from that, you
were creating a model
of how that meat behaved.

And that gave you parameters
that helped you interpret it.

ELLEN KUHL: Ideally, you
would know what you're saying.

Ideally, you would now
go back and say, OK,

what do we have to
change to adjust
certain properties of it?
Like, when does it fail?
How stiff is it?
How does it shear?

PAX: And what would-- so
this is a little off topic.
But what would that look like?

Would you have-- would you then
go back and say, well, what--

you would presumably now have
a model of real beef, of real--

and maybe even at different
stages of cooking.
I don't know.
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

So I mean, ideally, if you
can put these parameters--

I mean, we haven't done
all of this yet, obviously.
That would be great to have.

But that would be
a cool thing to do,

and then really have all
these different parameters

that influence the
mechanics of it,

and then the perception
of taste with that.
PAX: That's really interesting.

So we have some of these
more questions about--

so it's obviously one
thing if you're testing
a sort of artificial meat.

I mean, where are you
seeing the applications
in something like health care?

And I'm assuming
we're still-- and what
still needs to be done?

Because presumably, there's
a long way from going--

from modeling the heart to
creating it, or maybe not,
to creating an actual--

ELLEN KUHL: We've done this,
for example, for the brain.
So brain is super soft.
It's very difficult to test.

It was one of the last
materials that people really
got their hands on testing.
So you mentioned steel.

So there's this long history
where people initially

started testing very
stiff materials because it
was simple.
They don't deform much.
They're pretty linear.

You could just pretty
much stably test them.

And then the next thing
was muscle, then arteries,

and then probably other
softer tissues gels.

And then the brain
is the softest
of all biological tissues.

So it's the last kind of thing
that people try to study.

You think of the
football players
when they get a hit to the head.

What you want to do is
you want to translate

the deformation or the
acceleration of the helmet

into forces, and those
forces you apply to the head.

And then you can get a very
high resolution response
in terms of a stress profile.

And then you can even say,
Oh, this region of the brain

is most affected
by this head hit.

And that region is responsible
for motor skills, or language,
or vision, or whatever.

And so you can correlate the
hit to the head with a stress
profile with a function.
PAX: That's interesting.

And then in turn, that
might translate into how
you build a better helmet.
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

Or safer devices, or even
diagnose things, or in surgery,

if you have to cut
the brain, which

region is that you want to cut
and what's the safest region.

So there's a lot of mechanics
actually when you hit the head

and where you can really
apply these methods.

PAX: So we're getting
a question about how

about non-living matter,
so non-soft materials.

Can this be applied to
other kinds of materials,

and would there be advantages
over the traditional methods,

or is steel just
understood well enough
that maybe this is enough?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

So I think many of the
materials in their operating

range like steel are probably
relatively well understood.

Materials that are linear are
not difficult to discover.

You measure two points
and you fit a line.

So it's kind of from
a scientific point.
Not that interesting probably.

But all kinds of
gels, rubber materials

like, soft materials,
in general,

metamaterials where
people design materials

for certain functions, so
all kinds of materials,

you can apply it, in
general, for everything.

But these are materials where
it's probably most impactful.

So also say right now,
this is a new technology.

We're very confident using
it for elastic materials.

So when you load them and unload
them on the same behavior,

they don't have any permanent
deformations or damage.

Next step would be to
take this into something

that's time dependent,
temperature dependent.
Damage is failed.

And you could take this method
way beyond what it's currently
doing.

So there's a huge potential
to actually explore.

PAX: And would that be
in collecting more data?

So say, you're testing
a material right now

at room temperature, would
it be gathering more data
at different temperatures?

I mean, is there
a point where that

could be worked into
the constitutive part

of the neural network, where
the actual physics of how
these behave?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.

I mean, for instance,
temperature is a good one.

Certain materials--
polymers become glassy

when it's at
different temperatures
or change entirely their state.
Certain materials fail.

So for saying biomaterials,
it's pretty interesting

to know when they fail,
what much of a hit
can the brain tolerate.

It's not just in sports,
but in car accidents,
in the battlefield.

There's a lot of this that you
can actually test, and then
try to understand better.

Or, how do these tissues
interact with devices?

If you put a very
stiff device, a pacing

electrode into the
heart, or stimulation
into the brain, they usually--

like the engineering materials
matter is very stiff.

How does that interact
with a soft material?

PAX: And how does this
work for things like--

so we're getting a question
about modeling blood flow,

or something like
that for different--

is that a totally different--
is that kind of an a physics

level, a totally
different thing to model,

or is that something that
could also eventually
be tackled by this approach?
ELLEN KUHL: Yeah.
So that's a fluid.

So we have done this so
far for solids mainly,

but I think it could potentially
also do this for fluids.

We have actually one
application that's

just very recent, where we
looked at how Alzheimer's
spreads through the brain.
So that's not mechanics at all.
PAX: Interesting.

ELLEN KUHL: And then
we tried to discover

a model of the spreading
of Alzheimer's disease

through the brain based
on physics of spreading
and growth of this disease.

PAX: And so this was a similar
thing where you fed it data

and then it developed a
model and then you could--

so in that case, it's
maybe, interesting.

So it's then revolutionizing
how you understand

Alzheimer's or the
spread of Alzheimer's.
And would that--

I mean, so does that
potentially lead to treatments?
I mean, how would you in turn--

once you have a sense of
how it spreads, how do you--
how does that apply?

ELLEN KUHL: Where
does that apply?
PAX: Yeah.

ELLEN KUHL: So it helps you
understand the timeline.

It helps you understand
the different regions
in the brain that are affected.

Ideally, of course,
people want to understand

if they can halt it or
revert it or stop it.

The model itself would probably
not be able to tell you that,

but it can give you a lot more
information about regional,

which regions are affected at
which point of the disease,

and how does that kind of affect
the behavior of the person,
the decline in behavior.

And that's very
different because you

work with data that
has been collected

in patients and people
in disease, and not data
that you create yourself.

So in a way, you
have a lot of data,

but the data are not-- you can't
manipulate the data in a way
to get what you get.
PAX: Yeah.

We have-- so going a little bit
off topic, or not off topic,

but taking a little
bit of a pivot here.
So there's this question.

We have an interesting
question that came up,

that kind of if you're testing a
single material like the brain.

But you talked about
modeling a hit to the head.

So of course, at
that point, the force

is going through
skin, the skull.

So how do-- I mean,
I assume there are
traditional approaches to that.

ELLEN KUHL: Yeah, absolutely.

So you can do this

So you would just take

You section in

So there would be the skull.
There would be fluid.
There would be the brain itself.

There are ventricles

And so all of that can
have different properties.
You chop it in little pieces.

And every piece you
assign a certain material.

So you would test the
skin, and the skull,
and the brain itself.

And then everything has
a different stiffness.

And then when you hit
it, you can automatically

see reflection waves
at the interfaces
of certain materials.

Usually their stress
concentrations
have two different materials.

So that's very
interesting, because that's

where some diseases
happen eventually.
